title: How to Build a Bloody Mary Bar

steps.headline: Set out glasses.
steps.description: You’ll need enough glasses for each of your expected guests. It won’t hurt to have extras on hand in case someone shows up late or misplaces their drink. For a hearty cocktail like a Bloody Mary, go with a pint glass or large highball glass so the concoction doesn’t get too top heavy. One of these types of glasses will be spacious and sturdy enough to stand up to a mountain of garnishes. Mason jars with handles also make convenient containers, and tie in well to Southern-themed luncheons and cocktail parties.

steps.headline: Stock up on ice.
steps.description: Nobody wants a warm Bloody Mary. Get the ice maker working overtime the night before your get-together to make sure there's enough for multiple rounds. If you really want to go above and beyond, take the time to drop a few cubes into each glass once all of your guests are accounted for so they won't have to bother with it themselves. If you're expecting a big turnout, it may be easiest to pick up a few bags of ice from the store. Instead of using normal ice cubes, fill your freezer trays with a small batch of Bloody Mary mix. This will prevent your drinks from becoming watered down as they sit.

steps.headline: Keep a few shakers on standby.
steps.description: Whether you’re playing bartender or letting your guests handle the mixing duties themselves, you’ll need at least two or three shaker sets to speed things up. Place these down the length of the bar so that no one has to fight over who’s next. Place a separate dish or tray under each shaker set to catch drips and spills. Alternately, you could use a high-capacity blender to prepare the drinks.

steps.headline: Use pitchers to save time.
steps.description: If you’d rather take more of an assembly-line approach, you can whip up a batch of Bloody Marys in advance. That way, all your thirsty brunch-goers have to do is pour a glass and pick out their garnishes. Be sure to keep the pitchers refrigerated until it's time to serve them. Make big batches to standard strength with a mild level of spice and let everyone add to them as they see fit. A pitcher will also make it easier to refill glasses as they get low.

steps.headline: Put your garnishes on display.
steps.description: Arrange the garnishes neatly by category (pickled components in one row, olives in another, spicy condiments in another) to avoid confusion and keep the line moving. Make sure to place the serving dishes where they can be easily reached, and don’t forget to stick a fork or pair of tongs in each dish. Position popular items like celery sticks, limes, and dill sprigs closest to the front. Fill a nearby glass with long skewers that guests can use to keep all their garnishes neatly together.

steps.headline: Provide some basic mixing instructions.
steps.description: Lay down some note cards or hang a handmade sign with directions to help first-timers craft a basic cocktail. Configure the instructions to the layout of the bar—each drink might begin with a salted rim and end with a celery stick, lime wedge, and garnish skewer. Keep your directions simple and to the point so that guests can read them quickly on the move (“Salt the rim,” “Fill the glass with ice,” “Add the vegetable juice,” etc.). It's okay to vary your instructions based on what you like. For example, you might not like salting your rim, which is normal. You can skip this step.

steps.headline: Start with a basic vegetable juice.
steps.description: Tomato juice is the time-honored choice, but you could also use a blended vegetable juice like V8 to add some depth of flavor. If you’re in a crunch for time, it’s acceptable to pick up a bottle of Bloody Mary Mix. For best results, juice your own fresh vegetables at home just before you set up the bar.

steps.headline: Select a vodka you enjoy.
steps.description: Since a Bloody Mary contains a lot of flavor, you might not need a pricey vodka. Avoid flavored varieties of vodka, as these can throw off the taste of a Bloody Mary. Each drink should only get about 2oz. of vodka—otherwise, it can come out a little watery between the vegetable juice and the melting ice cubes. Try creating your own vodka infusions using additives like cucumbers, jalapeños or crushed herbs. One or two bottles should be more than enough for most casual gatherings—if you’re setting up at a wedding or another big event, take your guest list into account when placing your liquor order.

steps.headline: Squeeze some lemons and limes.
steps.description: Taking care of all your juicing at one time will cut down considerably on the amount of prep required for each cocktail. To ensure that you get just the right amount every time, transfer the juice to a couple miniature squeeze bottles. Wait until your lemons and limes have reached room temperature, then roll them on the bar top with the palm of your hand. This will loosen up the juice pods inside and allow you to extract more liquid from each fruit. Be sure to also fill a small dish with wedges to line the rim.

steps.headline: Put together your own spice blend.
steps.description: Rather than measuring each of the dry ingredients individually, portion them out into a single shaker. That way, your bartender or guests can simply add a couple dashes to each cocktail. A Bloody Mary typically calls for black pepper, sea salt, dried horseradish and plenty celery salt. For a unique twist on the classic recipe, you might also add a dash of white pepper, paprika, cayenne, ginger, or Old Bay seasoning.

steps.headline: Offer a variety of salts for the rim.
steps.description: Grind different salts and sprinkle them onto bread plates. In addition to the traditional celery salt, you can make room for coarse sea salt, garlic salt, or even homemade salts infused with flavors like lime or smoky ancho chiles. The salt plates should go at the end of the bar where guests first begin building their drinks.

steps.headline: Have a selection of hot sauces available.
steps.description: No Bloody Mary is complete without a splash of hot sauce, and there are different flavors and degrees of heat for every palette. Keep in mind that hot sauces should go into the cocktail before it’s mixed, not after. Use them sparingly to avoid overpowering the other flavors. If you want to keep things simple, a bottle of Tabasco or Tapatio will suffice. Those that are more daring might enjoy pushing their limits with sauces made from high-octane ingredients like habañeros or ghost peppers. Arrange your hot sauces from mild to molten, and be sure to label them so it’s obvious which is which.

steps.headline: Experiment with unconventional garnishes.
steps.description: Instead of a boring old celery stalk, shake things up by incorporating more vibrant offerings like cucumber spears, wild pearl onions or pickled okra. An abundance of options will ensure that every cocktail ends up being unique. Anything you can dream up is welcome on your Bloody Mary bar—pepperoncini, bell peppers, feta cheese, even sweeter sundries like pickled watermelon rind. A few sprigs of dill, basil, or cilantro will provide the finishing touches and serve as a pleasant color contrast.

steps.headline: Add a source of protein.
steps.description: A strip of bacon or beef jerky makes a perfect complement to the bold, savory notes of a Bloody Mary. Cocktails finished with meats are filling enough to serve as a meal in themselves. Sip and eat your way to the bottom of the glass and watch your drink disappear in record time. Check your local supermarket or party supply store for hollow meat straws. These can make a playful (and tasty) alternative to plastic straws. Having something to munch on will help hold your guests over until brunch is served.

steps.headline: Transform your Bloody Marys into hors d’oeuvres.
steps.description: An unassuming adult beverage can become an appetizer with the addition of some simple finger foods. Hang shrimp around the rim of each glass for a drinkable version of shrimp cocktail, or load your garnish skewers with cheese and olives and pair with a plate of crackers. The possibilities are practically endless! Combining your drinks and edibles will not only allow you be more creative when planning your bar setup, it will also cut down on cleanup time, since everything will be served in the same glass. As another option, you might add clam juice to your Bloody Mary to create a Bloody Caesar, which is a variation.
